<description type="note">Title: A mumming for the mercers of London.

45. A MUMMING FOR THE MERCERS OF LONDON.

[MS. Trin. Coll. Camb., R. 3. 20, pp. 171â175.] And nowe filoweÃ¾e a lettre made in wyse of balade by Daun Iohan, brought by a poursuyaunt in wyse of mommers desguysed to fore Ã¾e Mayre of London, Eestfeld, vpon Ã¾e twelffeÃ¾e night of Cristmasse, ordeyned ryallych by Ã¾e worthy merciers, citeseyns of London. 1 Moost mighty Lord, Iubyter Ã¾e Greet, Iubiter i. omnia iubens. Whos mansyoun is ouer Ã¾e sonnes beem, Frome Ã¾ens Ã¾at Phebus with his feruent heet Phebus i. sol. ReflecteÃ¾e his light vpon Ã¾e swyfft streeme Of Ewfratees towardes Ierusalem, Eufrates is oon of Ã¾e foure ffoodes of Paradys. Dovne coosteying, as bookys maken mynde, By Lubyes landes, thorughe Ethyope and Ynde; 2 Conveyed dovne, where Mars in Cyrrea Mars is god of batayle. HaÃ¾e bylt his paleys vpon Ã¾e sondes rede, And she, Venus, called Cytherrea, Venus is called Ã¾e goddesse of love. She is called Cytherea affter Cytheron, Ã¾e hill wher she is worshiped. Perseus is a knight which Ã¾at rood vpon an hors Ã¾at was called Pegase. Ãe nyen Muses dwelle bysyde Ellycon, Ã¾e welle; wheeche beon Ã¾e nyen sustres of Musyk and of Eloquences and Calyope is oone of hem. On Parnaso, with Pallas ful of drede; And Parseus with his furyous steede Smote on Ã¾e roche where Ã¾e Muses dwelle, Til Ã¾er sprange vp al sodeynly a welle, 3 Called Ã¾e welle of Calyope, Mooste auctorysed amonges Ã¾ees Cyryensâ; Of which Ã¾e poetes Ã¾at dwelle in Ã¾at cuntree, And oÃ¾er famous rethorycyens, And Ã¾ey Ã¾at cleped beon musycyens, Ar wont to drynk of Ã¾at hoolsome welle, Which Ã¾at alle oÃ¾er in vertu dooÃ¾e excelleâ; 4 Bacus is cleped god of wyne and Thagus is a ryver of which Ã¾e gravelles and Ã¾e sandes beon of golde. Tulius a poete and a rethorisyen of Rome. Macrobye an olde philosofre. Ovyde and Virgilius weren olde poetes, Ã¾at oon of Rome, Ã¾at oÃ¾er of Naples afore Ã¾e tyme of Cryst. Fraunceys Petrark was a poete of Florence. So were Bochas and Dante withinne Ã¾is hundreÃ¾e yeere; and Ã¾ey were called laureate for Ã¾ey were coroned with laurer in token Ã¾at Ã¾ey excelled oÃ¾er in poetrye. Poetes feynen Ã¾at Ã¾e gret god Iubiter came dovne from heven for to rauisshe a kynges doughter cleped Europa, affter whame alle Ã¾e cuntreys of Europ bereÃ¾e Ã¾e name.Where Bacus dwelleÃ¾e besydes Ã¾e ryver Of ryche Thagus, Ã¾e grauellys alle of gold, Which gyveÃ¾e a light agens Ã¾e sonne cleer, So fresshe, so sheene, Ã¾at hit may not beo tolde; Where Bellona haÃ¾e bylt a stately hooldeâ In al Ã¾is worlde, I trowe, Ã¾er is noon lycheâ Of harde magnetis and dyamandes ryche:â 5 And of Ã¾at welle drank some tyme Tulius And Macrobye, ful famous of prudence; Ovyde also, and eeke Virgilius, And Fraunceys Petrark, myrour of eloquence; Iohan Bocas also, flouring in sapyence. Thoroughe Ã¾at sugred bawme aureate Ãey called weren poetes laureate.â 6 Oute of Surrye, by many straunge stronde, Ãis Iubiter haÃ¾e his lettres sent, Thoroughe oute Europe, where he did lande, And frome Ã¾e heven came dovne of entent, To ravisshe shortly in sentement Fayre Europe, mooste renommed of fame, Affter whame yit al Europe bereÃ¾e Ã¾e name. 7 And thorughe Egypte his poursuyant is comme, Dovne descendid by Ã¾e Rede See, And haÃ¾e also his right wey ynomme Thoroughe valeye of Ã¾e Drye Tree By Flomme Iordan, coosteying Ã¾e cuntree, Where Iacob passed whylome with his staff, In baculo isto transiui Iordanem istum. Taking his shippe, to seylen at poort Iaff. 8 And so forÃ¾e downe his iourney can devyse, In Aquarye whane Phebus shoon ful sheene, Phebus in Aquario is als miche to seyne as Ã¾anne Ã¾e sonne is in pat signe.ForÃ¾e by passing Ã¾e gret gulff of Venyse; And sayled forÃ¾e soo al Ã¾e ryver of Geene; In which see regneÃ¾e Ã¾e mighty qweene, Called Cyrses, goddesse of waters salte, Cyrsees is a goddesse of Ã¾e see, which turneÃ¾e men into liknesse of bestis, and nymphes ben goddesses of smale ryvers. Where nymphes syng, hir honnour to exalte. 9 And Ã¾er he saughe, as he gan approche, With inne a boote a fissher drawe his nette On Ã¾e right syde of a crystal rooche; Fisshe was Ã¾er noon, for Ã¾e draught was lette. And on Ã¾oon syde Ã¾er were lettres sette Ãat sayde in Frenshe Ã¾is raysoun: Grande travayle; Ãis aunswere nexst in ordre: Nulle avayle. 10 Ãanne seyling forÃ¾e bysyde many a rokk, He gane ful fast for to haaste him dovne Thoroughe Ã¾e daunger and streytes of Marrokk, Passing Ã¾e parayllous currant of Arragoun; So foorÃ¾e by Spaygne goyng envyroun, Thoroughe out Ã¾e Raas and rokkes of Bretaygne, Ãe Brettysshe see til Ã¾at he did atteyne 11 Thoroughe Ã¾ilk sakk, called of Poortland; And towardes Caleys holding his passage, Lefft Godwyn sandes, by grace of Goddes handâ Havyng his wynde to his avauntage, Ãe weder cleer, Ã¾e stormes lefft hir raageâ Entryng Ã¾e see of Brutes Albyon, Nowe called Themse thoroughe al Ã¾is regyon. 12 And in a ffeeld, Ã¾at droughe in to Ã¾e eest, Besyde an ylande, he saughe a shippe vnlade Which hade sayled ful fer towarde Ã¾e West; Ãe caban peynted with floures fresshe and glaade And lettres Frenshe, Ã¾at feynt nyl ne faade: Taunt haut e bas que homme soyt, Touz ioures regracyer dieux doyt. 13 And in a boote on Ã¾at oÃ¾er syde AnoÃ¾er fissher droughe his nette also, Neptunus is also a goddesse of Ã¾e seeFul of gret fisshe (Neptunus was his guyde), With so gret plentee, he nyst what til do. And Ã¾er were lettres enbrouded not fer froo, Ful fresshly wryten Ã¾is worde: grande peyne; A[nd] cloos acording with Ã¾is resoun: grande gayne. 14 Ãe noble yllande, where he saughe Ã¾is sight, Gaf vn-to him a demonstracion, Taught him also by Ã¾e Poolys light, He was not fer frome Londones tovne. And with a floode Ã¾e pursuyaunt came downe, Lefft Ã¾e water, and at Thems stronde, With owte aboode, in haaste he came to lande, 15 From Egypt to London, Iupiter's herald has come to gladden the noble Mayor.Where certayne vesselles nowe by Ã¾e anker ryde. Hem to refresshe and to taken ayr, Certein estates, wheche purveye and provyde For to vysyte and seen Ã¾e noble Mayr Of Ã¾is cytee and maken Ã¾eyre repayr To his presence, or Ã¾at Ã¾ey firÃ¾er flitte, Vnder supporte, Ã¾at he wol hem admytte.
